Message.Title: Obama's Bay Area Trip was a Huge Success
Message.Msg: His plane landed at SFO, putting flights carrying common citizens on hold. He visited billionaire elites, raising millions of dollars campaigning for democrats at $32,500 a plate meals of only the finest, rarest endangered ingredients while the poor starved. His motorcade disrupted traffic, leaving thousands of cars idling in traffic while emitting tons of unnecessary pollution. There were so many complaints about this "president of the poor and underprivileged" displaying wasteful and extravagant behaviors at taxpayers expense that he relented and had the limo swing by a soup kitchen to rub elbows with the needy. But when he got there, there was no-one. The manager of the soup kitchen apologized, saying that they had run out of rice and beans. Obama, obviously puzzled and bothered as to why the wealthiest nation on earth cannot feeds its underprivileged, was indignant at his loss of a photo op, and as he stormed back into the limo he said, "They couldn't just feed them cake?" "Let them eat cake!" "There was plenty of cake in Atherton last night!"

Message.Title: this week, april 7
Message.Msg: This week, April 7th Asst to the President Dan Pfeiffer gave us about ten minutes of administration thoughts—There will be no deal with the House if its attitude of ‘My way or the highway’ continues. Later mention of House GOP view—the president got his tax increase a few months back with small increase in tax rate for the affluent. Yes the president wants a quality “gun control” bill And any “chained” CPI index consideration of future social security increases depends upon being part of a larger package including “compromises” Then g f Will started, with statement that China does have leverage with N Korea, especially via its provision of oil to North Korea. ABC’s Martha Raddatz, recently on the Korean peninsula, feels “best result” of the anticipated N Korean rocket launch would be a quick fall into the ocean. Paul Krugman considers the job growth report bad news, blames “sequester” and the return of FICA payments to its prior 6.2 per cent rate. David Stockman of Reagan govt fame feels “Washington is failing”; Krugman considers employment figures do or should represent work force aging (compared with a decade ago, etc). Greta van Susteren of “Fox” blames “regulations” for hurting small business and blames Congress for “doing nothing” when it “should be working”. Krugman—how dare there be mention of “higher interest rates” in a declining economy? Instead of indignation re Atlanta teachers cheating re student test scores, it was pointed out that linking student test scores to teacher salaries and tenure is unwise. Sponsors—oil pressure group again, Chevron, Xerox returns, GE twice, Ameriprise (closest financial sponsor), and yes Pacific Life and United Health Care, the latter gently pushing worker health improvements as desirable. Even Roger Ebert not mentioned, but a reference to M L King’s assassination was included, as was mention of two in USA military who made the ultimate sacrifice in Afghanistan—one (South Carolina) age 43, the other age 29, from

Message.Title: The ruling few
Message.Msg: "Worried about the 1 percent? Don't be. Worry about the 0.05 percent. That's the percentage of Americans who maxed out their contribution to any political candidate in the last election. Or the 0.01 percent who made contributions of $10,000 or more. That's the number of Americans who actually show up on the radar of politicians. But those are only flyspecks on the screen. Save your real worry for the 0.000042 percent. That's 132 people. Those 132 people provided 60 percent of all the money that ended up in Super PACs. If you're a politician, and you spend between 30 and 70 percent of your time begging for funds for the next election cycle, as American politicians do ... who you gonna call?

Topic.Title: What should the minimum wage be?

Message.Msg: Once again, the stupidest argument in all of pandering propaganda-based politics. Your strawman suggests that a minimum wage job should be the end goal, rather than the entry level that it actually is. The idea - for those too stupid to understand - is to get experience and move out of minimum wage, so I guess we all know that raising the minimum wage will increase your salary as a fryboy. You prove that NO liberal ever thinks beyond the end of their nose, but each is consistently filled with completely worthless emotion, and constantly makes stupid emotional decisions. So why would anyone be concerned about making minimum wage a "living wage" if the point of minimum wage jobs is to be an entry point for the inexperienced on which to gain experience? Your ideas are nothing more than value destroyer and job killers. You might want to silence yourself before you sprain that teeny tiny emotion-laden propaganda-filled brain.

The chimpanzees are usually contained by a moat and a high fence to keep them from running amok, AND to keep them under control. So it is also with the right-wingers. They are also permitted to run loose within a closely monitored zone where they are allowed to express their inferior creature perversions. But, they will NEVER do any damage beyond being offensive. Message.Title: Rahm Emmanuel supports Banks on the Backs of the Poor - Rahm for the 2016 Republican Canidate
Message.Msg: Last month, the Chicago Board of Education announced it would close 54 schools, affecting 30,000 children, mostly in low-income, African-American neighborhoods on the city’s South and West sides. Mayor Rahm Emanuel and Chicago Public Schools board members want us to believe that they must close schools to save money, but that is simply not true. They are choosing to close schools while sending millions of dollars to Wall Street. Every year, CPS pays approximately $36 million in toxically high interest rates, linked to so-called swap contracts, to banks like Bank of America and Goldman Sachs. These arrangements, in which CPS pays a fixed interest rate to the banks — typically between 3.5 and 5.25 percent — to protect itself against fluctuating interest rates in the bond market, were supposed to save CPS money. But the arrangements backfired — and became morally reprehensible — when the banks crashed the economy and the Federal Reserve slashed interest rates to bail them out. Now the banks are profiting greatly from the federal bailout, but Chicago’s schools get nothing — no such relief for them from crippling high interest rates — even as the banks continue to extract millions of dollars from CPS. Big banks were saved by public money, but many Chicago communities are besieged by record high unemployment and foreclosure rates. After jeopardizing our jobs and our homes, now these banks are coming for our children’s schools. We need a mayor who will stand up to Wall Street and fight for our communities. But rather than demanding that these banks renegotiate the swap deals, as other cities successfully have done, Emanuel is choosing to close 54 schools. CPS claims the closures will save an average of $60 million a year for 10 years — numbers that many studies have shown are based on unrealistic assumptions, such as the district being able to sell 50 percent of shuttered schools. At the same time, CPS fails to account for the cost to the children who must cross new g
